titleStmt.title: To the Reverend Doctor Swift, Dean of St. Patrick's, sending

publicationStmt.p: Distributed by Digital Scholarship Services at Lafayette College

lg.l: TO thee, Dear Swift, these spotless Leaves I send,
Small is the Present, but sincere the Friend;
Think not so poor a Book below thy Care,
Who knows the Price that thou can'st make it bear?
Though tawdry now and like Tyrilla's Face,
The spacious Front shines out with borrow'd Grace;
Though Paste-boards glittering like a Tinsel Coat,
A rasa Tabula within denote:
Yet if a venal and corrupted Age,
And Modern Vices sho'd provoke thy rage,
If warn'd once more by their impending Fate,
A sinking Country and an injur'd State,
The great Assistance should again demand,
And call forth Reason to defend the Land:
Then shall we view these Sheets with glad Suprize,
Inspir'd with Thought, and speaking to our Eyes;
Each vacant Space shall then enrich'd d·spence
True Force of Eloquence and nervous Sense,
Inform the Judgment, animate the Heart,
And sacred Rules of Policy impart;
The spangl'd Cov'ring bright with splendid Oar,
Shall cheat the Sight with empty Shew no more,
But lead us inward to those Golden Mines
Where all thy Soul in Native Lustre shines.So when the Eye surveys some lovely Fair,
With Bloom and Beauty, grac'd with Shape and Air,
How is the Rapture heighten·d, when we find
Her Form excell'd by her Celestial Mind.609-33QA
